blow.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: if the wind or a current of air blows, it moves
blow.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: A cold breeze was blowing hard.
It was blowing from an easterly direction.
Outside, the weather was blowing a gale.
blow.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to move, or to move something, by the force of the wind or a current of air
blow.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Her hair was blowing in the breeze.
The wind blew the rain into our faces.
A sudden draught blew the door shut.
blow.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to send air out from your mouth
blow.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: He blew the smoke right in my face.
She blew onto her coffee to cool it down.
blow.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to make a sound by passing air through a whistle, horn etc
blow.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: The whistle blew for half time.
A truck went by and blew its horn at her.
blow.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to damage or destroy something violently with an explosion or by shooting
blow.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: A bomb like that could blow you to bits.
Part of his leg had been blown off.
blow.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to lose a good opportunity by making a mistake or by being careless
blow.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: We’ve blown our chances of getting that contract.
You’ve got a great future ahead of you. Don’t blow it.
blow.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to spend a lot of money in a careless way, especially on one thing
blow.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: I blew all the money I won on a trip to Hawaii.
blow.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: if an electrical fuse blows, or a piece of electrical equipment blows a fuse, the electricity suddenly stops working because a thin wire has melted
blow.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: if a tyre blows, or if a car blows a tyre, it bursts
blow.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: to make or shape something by sending air out from your mouth
blow glass (=shape glass by blowing into it when it is very hot and soft)
blow.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: The kids were blowing bubbles in the backyard.
blow.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: to make known something that was meant to be a secret
blow.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: Your coming here has blown the whole operation.
It would only take one phone call to blow his cover.
blow.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: Blow belongs to a group of verbs where the same noun can be the subject of the verb or its object
blow.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1]: In this sentence, ‘a whistle’ is the object of blow
blow.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2]: In this sentence, ‘a whistle’ is the subject of blow
blow.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: an action or event that causes difficulty or sadness for someone
blow.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Joe resigned, which was a severe blow because we needed him desperately.
His mother’s death was a shattering blow.
The election result dealt a further blow to the party.
The factory closures came as a blow to the local economy.
The final blow for many firms was the government’s abolition of import duties.
blow.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a hard hit with someone’s hand, a tool, or a weapon
blow.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: She died from a heavy blow to the head.
He struck a blow which threw her to the floor.
Martin received a blow on the nose.
He had been struck a glancing blow (=a blow that did not hit him directly) by the car.
He gave her a violent blow to the head.
blow.translation[1].definitions[1].note_: In everyday English, people usually say that someone gets hit or that something hits them, rather than using the noun blow:
blow.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: One big blow and the candles were out.
blow.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: ADJECTIVES/NOUN + blow
a big/major/serious/heavy blow
The earthquake was a serious blow to the area’s tourism industry.
a severe/terrible/awful blow
The news was a terrible blow for his family.
a bitter blow
Their defeat was a bitter blow.
a cruel/devastating/crushing blow
Her loss came as a devastating blow to her father.
a body blow
A tax on books would be a body blow for education.
a mortal/fatal/death blow
When he quit it dealt a mortal blow to the show.
be a blow
I can’t deny his leaving was a blow.
deal a blow to somebody/something
The 1982 drought dealt a devastating blow to the country.
come as a blow to somebody
His sudden death came as a huge blow to us all.
deliver a blow
Opinion polls delivered a nasty blow to the Tory leader.
suffer/receive a blow
Our team suffered a blow when Paul was sent off the field.
soften/cushion the blow
There are various ways to soften the blow of redundancy among staff.
be a bit of a blow
The result was a bit of a blow for the team.
blow.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: if you blow money on something, you spend a lot of money on it, often money that you cannot afford
blow.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: He blew his wages on a new stereo.
blow.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to tell the authorities that someone in your organization is doing something illegal, dishonest, or wrong
blow.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: Workers were too scared of their employers to blow the whistle on illegal working hours.
